Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Use of Zeolite as a Natural Algaecide
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an innovation to reduce freshwater harmful algae blooms (FHABs) resulting from nutrient pollution that threaten aquatic ecosystems and water resources. Conservation of water resources has become a necessity all around the world and the development of new techniques for obtaining and maintaining fresh water is now needed. This innovation will strengthen the U.S. economy, protect human and animal health, and help preserve our nation's freshwater bodies. Furthermore, this technology has applications that increase environmental, social, and economic aspects of sustainability locally, regionally, and globally. Currently, efforts to control FHABs in lakes containing aquatic life has been limited to mechanical cleansing or the use of chemical-based algaecides. Eutrophication and FHABs are conservatively estimated to cost the U.S. economy 2.2â€“4.6 billion dollars. <br/><br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a copper-modified natural zeolite (Cu-Z) as an algaecide, a chemical approach that avoids leaving a residual in water and soil as the copper is immobilized within the zeolite matrix. Cu-Z also provides the flexibility of implementing it in different configurations such as filtration units or in-situ static or moving flotation devices. Batch test experiments have been performed in which the efficacy of using Cu-Zeolite has been tested using chlorophyll a as an indicator of algae in water. Also, samples of water containing algae grown in a fish tank, commercially purchased algae, and algae from a local lake have been tested by analyzing for fluorescence levels before and after exposure to copper solutions and Cu-Zeolite. Preliminary results have shown that the Cu-Zeolite may be as effective as a Copper solution to inhibit algae growth. The use of Cu-Zeolite may provide a safer and cost-effective alternative for preventing algae growth in drinking water storage tanks, pools, and ponds. Additional studies are being conducted to ensure that the copper residuals in water resulting from the use of the Cu-Zeolite as algaecide are safe for aquatic life or drinking water.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fresh water Harmful Algal Blooms (FHABs)  biomass and toxins threaten the sustainability of aquatic ecosystems and harm people, animals, drinking water supplies, property values, and recreational activities like swimming and fishing. Currently efforts to manage nutrient pollution in lakes containing aquatic life have been limited to mechanical cleansing or the use of chemical-based algaecides. However, these efforts are not sufficient because they require more time and capital investment than the use of a non-toxic algaecide or phytoremediation. The proposed innovation consists of a copper-modified natural zeolite (Cu-Z) as an algaecide, a chemical approach that avoids leaving a residual in water and soil and provides the flexibility of implementing it in different configurations such as filtration units or in-situ static or moving flotation devices.

The CuZ team participated in the 2021 iCorps Winter Cohort hosted by the New York City Regional Innovation Node in 2021. Throughout the program, the team was able to identify possible customer segments in the public and private sector. For the program’s duration, the team focused on the public customer segmentation, most specifically with surface water engineers. By refining the value proposition through customer interviews, the team was able to identify that the best value for water engineers would be the ability to run the water plant at full capacity without worrying about mechanical problems caused by algae buildup. A total of 116 interviews were conducted with potential customers and key players that make up our customer ecosystem as shown in Figure 1. The team was also able to determine a more refined estimation of the potential market sizing using the TAM/SAM approach as illustrated in Figure 2.

Based on the feedback received from our potential customers, direct sales as revenue streams and product volume pricing were proposed as a possible model. The team was also able to calculate an estimated customer value/acquisition cost strengthening the argument for commercialization. By the end of the program, the team completed the business model canvas shown in Figure 3. We were able to validate some of its sections, as shown in the color-coded figure with green representing validation, yellow further validation needed, and red not validated at all. The team was able to identify that the venture and customer discovery still needed further work but held a potential opportunity for commercialization.

The team attended five conferences related to water quality, where they were able to learn about other existing technologies as well as conduct interviews with engineers and practitioners dealing with FHABs, some of which were identified as potential customers and possible technological competition.
